resources.string: Taking the reigns on your personal finance

The key to sound financial footing in life begins with knowing where your money is coming from and where it is going and the best way to begin this is with budgeting. This not only involves attempting to minimise outgoings the best you can but also with figuring out your goals and what the best strategy is going forward to reach those. This app is designed to help you help you realise your spending and gain knowledge on how moving forward your money may better be put to work for you.

Key to a strong financial situation is education about finance. Knowing your sources of income, where your expenses are and where the rest is being saved or invested. So really we could simplify personal finance down to just 3 steps. Earn more, spend less, invest the rest. Easy right\? Unfortunately it\'s not quite that simple or easy. Hence why we\'re starting here and seeing what steps we can take almost instantly to reduce unnecessary bills and put our money to work for us. To begin, let\'s start with your monthly take home, so after tax and national insurance is deducted and we\'ll see how we can improve!

No one likes to think about it but sometimes things don\'t go in our favour. In the UK around 26%% people have savings of less than £1,000. Take a moment to think about how long this would last you if from tomorrow your income disappeared. An emergency fund aims to reduce this worry by keeping an accessible sum of money aside that you don\'t touch unless something unexpected happens which catches you off guard. This should be set aside and not as a pot to dip into, instead only for genuine emergencies. The optimal emergency fund can be anywhere from 6 months outgoings to 12 months depending on your risk appetite and this gives you that extra piece of mind so you don\'t need to worry. Also your first priority once your back on your feet is to replenish its value. Look after your emergency fund so it can look after you!

Financially it is alway\'s logical to minimise your outgoings. Whilst eliminating or reducing housing costs, utilities and the basics is much easier said than done a good place to begin is with \'entertainment\' costs. Don\'t worry! We\'re not saying stop doing all the things you enjoy or cut out socialising but getting creating a picture of where your income is being spent is vital to identifying areas where you may be overspending and could pull the reigns on to save some money aside for other longer term goals. Here you can enter your average monthly outgoings and we can crunch the numbers.

Before anyone can think about long term saving and investing its best to remove any short term leaks and get debts paid off. enter below if you have any high interest debt (>4%) excluding student loans. We will look at repayment methods later if necessary.

For many people retirement feels like another lifetime away but it is never too early to consider your future self. You should ensure your are enrolled in your employer\'s automatic enrolment pension scheme. This is a minimum of 3%% extra pay in exchange for you contributing 4%% of your take-home pay. Enter below if you know your enrolled in such a scheme.

Purchasing a house is often the top priority for many people and likely to be the biggest purchase they will make in their lives. Saving for a deposit and any relevant fees can depend on time frames and cost so it can be reassuring to know you are saving in the most effective way possible for the future. Enter below if you are saving currently for your first home along with the time frame in which you intend to purchase.

Having something to work towards is key for motivation to save and in showing yourself that you can be financially responsible. Enter below if you have any short term goals ( less than 5 years and excluding buying your first home).

As we mentioned earlier about setting up your workplace pensions and ensuring maximum contributions, Thinking of the future is absolutely vital to not only look after your future self but give your current self piece of mind and reassurance. Enter below if you have any longer terms goals and whether these occur before or after you reach retirement account so we can find the best options.
Your monthly expenses are %d%% of what you take home. This is higher than ideal so we should look at where your spending is going and try to bring it below 50%% if we can!
Your monthly expenses are %d%% of what you take home. We\'re on track so far and your spending is not out of control!
Well done! you\'ve achieved your target of £%1$d (6 months outgoings). Now keep this set aside in an account you can easily access quickly and has a good interest rate to earn a return on this.
Your target of £%1$d has not quite been reached yet. Try and set some more aside each month if you can to build this up closer to the target of 6 months outgoings.
You stated that you apply the maximum contribution to your workplace pension including matched contributions. This is great news and is sure you set you up well for the future should you continue.
You\'ve stated you dont yet give your maximum contribution or are unsure. Make it your mission to find out what your employer offers and look into getting the benefits of this scheme!
It looks like you have some higher interest debts that could do with wiping out to restore some of your monthly income. Click the get advice button below to find out how to tackle these debts best.
You didn\'t enter any high interest debts previously. Thats great and we should aim to keep it this way if we can due to their potential drain on incomes
You don\'t need to worry about this section!

You\'ve entered that it will be around %d years until you purchase your first home. This is fairly long term and that money otherwise set in a savings or current account could be gaining more value. Consider a LISA for a 25%% bonus on up to £4000 a year and the rest could go placed into an index fund.

%d years isn\'t long term enough to be considering higher risk methods of gaining value. Aim to keep your deposit in a savings account with a respectable interest rate until you need the cash. You can still benefit from a LISA too if you aren\'t already!
